name.text: Give statement forms of the axioms of an enigma and answer to an enigma.

questiontext.text:
Consider the following enigma problem, and give statement forms of its axioms. Then fill in the truth table, and answer to the enigma: "Who order a dessert and not".

Problem:Three Colleagues, Albert, Bernard and Charles, have lunch together every working day.
The following axioms are true:

  1. If Albert orders a dessert, Bernard orders one too.
  2. Every day, either Bernard or Charles, but not both, orders a dessert.
  3. Albert or Charles, or both, order dessert daily.
  4. If Charles orders dessert, Albert does the same.

Statement forms of axioms
Give the statement form of each axiom given in the problem.
Let a: "Albert orders a dessert",      b: "Bernard orders a dessert", and c: "Charles orders a dessert".
1. "If Albert orders a dessert, Bernard orders one too": [[input:ans34]] [[validation:ans34]]  [[feedback:prt10]]
2. "Every day, either Bernard or Charles, but not both, orders a dessert": [[input:ans35]] [[validation:ans35]]  [[feedback:prt11]]
3. "Albert or Charles, or both, order dessert daily": [[input:ans36]] [[validation:ans36]]  [[feedback:prt12]]
4. "If Charles orders dessert, Albert does the same": [[input:ans37]] [[validation:ans37]]  [[feedback:prt13]]

Fill in truth table

\(a\) \(b\) \(c\) \(a \implies b\) \((b \land \neg c) \lor (\neg b \land c)\) \(a \lor c\) \(c \implies a\)
\({@p[1]@}\) \({@q[1]@}\) \({@p[1]@}\) [[input:ans1]] [[input:ans9]] [[input:ans17]] [[input:ans25]] [[feedback:prt1]]
\({@p[1]@}\) \({@q[1]@}\) \({@p[2]@}\) [[input:ans2]] [[input:ans10]] [[input:ans18]] [[input:ans26]] [[feedback:prt2]]
\({@p[1]@}\) \({@q[2]@}\) \({@p[1]@}\) [[input:ans3]] [[input:ans11]] [[input:ans19]] [[input:ans27]] [[feedback:prt3]]
\({@p[1]@}\) \({@q[2]@}\) \({@p[2]@}\) [[input:ans4]] [[input:ans12]] [[input:ans20]] [[input:ans28]] [[feedback:prt4]]
\({@p[2]@}\) \({@q[1]@}\) \({@p[1]@}\) [[input:ans5]] [[input:ans13]] [[input:ans21]] [[input:ans29]] [[feedback:prt5]]
\({@p[2]@}\) \({@q[1]@}\) \({@p[2]@}\) [[input:ans6]] [[input:ans14]] [[input:ans22]] [[input:ans30]] [[feedback:prt6]]
\({@p[2]@}\) \({@q[2]@}\) \({@p[1]@}\) [[input:ans7]] [[input:ans15]] [[input:ans23]] [[input:ans31]] [[feedback:prt7]]
\({@p[2]@}\) \({@q[2]@}\) \({@p[2]@}\) [[input:ans8]] [[input:ans16]] [[input:ans24]] [[input:ans32]] [[feedback:prt8]]

Answer to the enigma: Who orders a dessert?

Note: Hint: Observe from the truth table the interpretation that makes all four statement forms true.

 [[input:ans33]] [[validation:ans33]]  [[feedback:prt9]]

[[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]] [[validation:ans3]] [[validation:ans4]] [[validation:ans5]] [[validation:ans6]] [[validation:ans7]] [[validation:ans8]] [[validation:ans17]] [[validation:ans18]] [[validation:ans19]] [[validation:ans20]]

[[validation:ans9]] [[validation:ans10]] [[validation:ans11]] [[validation:ans12]] [[validation:ans13]] [[validation:ans14]] [[validation:ans15]] [[validation:ans16]] [[validation:ans21]] [[validation:ans22]] [[validation:ans23]] [[validation:ans24]]

[[validation:ans25]] [[validation:ans26]] [[validation:ans27]] [[validation:ans28]][[validation:ans29]] [[validation:ans30]] [[validation:ans31]] [[validation:ans32]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Statement forms of axioms:
Give the statement form of each axiom given in the problem.
Let a: "Albert orders a dessert", b: "Bernard orders a dessert", and c: "Charles orders a dessert".
1. "If Albert orders a dessert, Bernard orders one too": a implies b
2. "Every day, either Bernard or Charles, but not both, orders a dessert": (b and not c) or (not b and c)
3. "Albert or Charles, or both, order dessert daily": a or c
4. "If Charles orders dessert, Albert does the same": c implies a

Fill in truth table: Here are the truth tables of each of these statements

Truth table of \(a \implies b\): {@truth_table(ta1)@}

Truth table of ( \( b \land \neg c\) ) \(\lor\)  ( \(\neg b \land c\) ): {@truth_table(P1)@}

Truth table of \( a \lor c \): {@truth_table(ta3)@}

Truth table of \( c \implies a \): {@truth_table(ta4)@}

Answer to the enigma: Who order a dessert and who does not order a dessert?
We deduction that the interpretation that makes all four statement forms true is the second line from the truth table.
One can see that only "a" and "b" are true and "c" is false. Therefore, Albert and Bernard order dessert but not Charles.

questionnote.text: Note: There is no randomization in this question

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.
